## The play called *The King in Yellow*

The fictional play *The King in Yellow* has at least two acts and at least three characters: Cassilda, Camilla and "the Stranger", who may or may not be the titular character.

Chambers' story collection excerpts some sections from the play to introduce the book as a whole, or individual stories. For example, "Cassilda's Song" comes from Act 1, Scene 2 of the play:"The King in Yellow" in e.g.

The short story "The Mask" is introduced by an excerpt from Act 1, Scene 2d:"The Mask" in e.g.

It is also stated, in "The Repairer of Reputations", that the final moment of the first act involves the character Camilla's "agonized scream and [...] awful words echoing through the dim streets of Carcosa".

All of the excerpts come from Act I. The stories describe Act I as quite ordinary, but reading Act II drives the reader mad with the "irresistible" revealed truths: "The very banality and innocence of the first act only allowed the blow to fall afterward with more awful effect". Even seeing the first page of the second act is enough to draw the reader in: "If I had not caught a glimpse of the opening words in the second act I should never have finished it" ("[Repairer of Reputations](The)(The Repairer of Reputations)").

Chambers usually gives only scattered hints of the contents of the full play, as in this extract from "The Repairer of Reputations":

He mentioned the establishment of the Dynasty in Carcosa, the lakes which connected Hastur, Aldebaran and the mystery of the Hyades. He spoke of Cassilda and Camilla, and sounded the cloudy depths of Demhe, and the Lake of Hali. "The scolloped tatters of the King in Yellow must hide Yhtill forever", he muttered, but I do not believe Vance heard him. Then by degrees he led Vance along the ramifications of the Imperial family, to Uoht and Thale, from Naotalba and Phantom of Truth, to Aldones, and then tossing aside his manuscript and notes, he began the wonderful story of the Last King.

A similar passage occurs in "The Yellow Sign", in which two protagonists have read *The King in Yellow*:

Night fell and the hours dragged on, but still we murmured to each other of the King and the Pallid Mask, and midnight sounded from the misty spires in the fog-wrapped city. We spoke of Hastur and of Cassilda, while outside the fog rolled against the blank window-panes as the cloud waves roll and break on the shores of Hali.

The fictional play within 'The King in Yellow' is also titled The King in Yellow. In Robert W. Chambers' book, this play is infamous for driving those who read its second act into madness or despair. The first act appears ordinary, but the contents of the second act reveal "irresistible" truths that cause psychological and existential collapse among readers. The play features characters such as Cassilda, Camilla, and "the Stranger," and is filled with mysterious references like Carcosa, Hastur, and the Lake of Hali.

In summary, The King in Yellow is the fictional play that induces despair or madness within the book of the same name.

### 2021–present: *Desire, I Want to Turn Into You*

[[Polachek - First Avenue 12-7-2021 45.jpg|thumb|right|Polachek performing in 2021](File:Caroline)]

In September 2021, Polachek was announced as one of the opening acts on [Lipa](Dua)(Dua Lipa)'s [Nostalgia Tour](Future)(Future Nostalgia Tour). The tour began on February 9, 2022. On November 4, 2021, Charli XCX released "[Shapes](New)(New Shapes)" featuring Christine and the Queens and Polachek as the second single from her studio album *[Crash](Crash (Charli XCX album))* (2022).

On July 14, 2021, Polachek released the single "[Is a Rider](Bunny)(Bunny Is a Rider)", another collaboration with Harle; she told *[Crack](Crack (magazine))* magazine that the song was part of a future project. In December, *[Pitchfork](Pitchfork (website))* ranked "Bunny Is a Rider" at the top of their list of "The 100 Best Songs of 2021". On February 9, 2022, Polachek released the single "[Billions](Billions (Caroline Polachek song))". In March, she was featured on Australian electronic music producer [Flume](Flume (musician))'s single "Sirens", released ahead of his upcoming studio album [*Palaces*](Palaces (album)). In June, Polachek confirmed that she was working on her fourth studio album, posting a picture of herself in studio with Danny L Harle on [Instagram](Instagram). She recorded a cover version of "[Bang (My Baby Shot Me Down)](Bang)(Bang Bang (My Baby Shot Me Down))" for the [The Rise of Gru* soundtrack album](*Minions:)(Minions: The Rise of Gru (soundtrack)), released on July 1, 2022. On October 17, her flamenco-inspired single "Sunset", a co-production with [Bodega](Sega)(Sega Bodega), was released.

On December 5, 2022, Polachek released the single "[to My Island](Welcome)(Welcome to My Island)" and announced her second studio album under her full name, *[I Want to Turn Into You](Desire,)(Desire, I Want to Turn Into You)*, for release on February 14, 2023. The album received critical acclaim and includes "Bunny Is a Rider", "Billions", "Sunset", and "Welcome to My Island".
Caroline Polachek released the critically acclaimed album Desire, I Want to Turn Into You in 2023. This album includes the single "Bunny Is a Rider."

## Early life

Klementieff was born in [City](Quebec)(Quebec City), [Quebec](Quebec), Canada to a Korean mother, Yu Ri Park, and Russian-French father Alexis Klementieff,The Canada Gazette, vol. 119, collected issues 40-43, 1985, p. 6445World Guide to Foreign Services, vol. 1, World Guides Internationale Publikationen, 1986, p. 261 who was working there as a consul with the government of France. She is a French citizen, but does not have Canadian citizenship because *[soli](jus)(jus soli)* does not apply to children of diplomats.Additional  on 7 July 2014. Her grandfather was Russian painter Eugene Klementieff (1901-c.1985). Her parents chose the name "Pom" because it is similar in pronunciation to the Korean words for both "spring" () and "tiger" (). Klementieff lived in Canada for one year before her family began traveling extensively due to her father's job. They lived in Japan and Ivory Coast before settling in France.

Klementieff's father died of cancer when she was five, and her mother had [schizophrenia](schizophrenia) and was unable to care for children, so Klementieff was raised by her paternal uncle and aunt. Her uncle, whom she described as "like [her] second father", died on her 18th birthday, and her older brother Namou died by suicide seven years later, on her 25th birthday. Klementieff briefly studied law in an undergraduate capacity after her uncle's death to appease her aunt, but did not find it appealing. She also worked as a waitress and saleswoman in France. She started acting at age 19 at the [Florent](Cours)(Cours Florent) drama school in Paris. A few months into her education, she won a theater competition and two years of free classes with the school's top teachers.

# Pom Klementieff

*Revision ID: 1160114424 | Timestamp: 2023-06-14T14:01:50Z*

---

| birth_place        = [City](Quebec)(Quebec City), Quebec, Canada

| nationality        = French

| education          = [Florent](Cours)(Cours Florent)

| occupation         = Actress

| years_active       = 2007–present

| signature          = Pom Klementieff signature.svg

}}

**Pom Alexandra Klementieff** (; born 3 May 1986Additional  on 1 January 2018.) is a French actress. She was trained at the [Florent](Cours)(Cours Florent) drama school in Paris and appeared in such French films as *[Easy Way](The)(The Easy Way (film))* (2008) and *[Night](Sleepless)(Sleepless Night (2011 film))* (2011), before making her American film debut in *[Oldboy](Oldboy (2013 film))* (2013). In 2019, she also made an appearance in *[Vipers](Striking)(Striking Vipers)*, the first episode of the fifth series of the anthology series *[Mirror](Black)(Black Mirror)*.

Klementieff received worldwide recognition for her role as [Mantis](Mantis (Marvel Cinematic Universe)) in the [Cinematic Universe](Marvel)(Marvel Cinematic Universe) films *[of the Galaxy Vol. 2](Guardians)(Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 2)* (2017), *[Infinity War](Avengers:)(Avengers: Infinity War)* (2018), *[Endgame](Avengers:)(Avengers: Endgame)* (2019), *[Love and Thunder](Thor:)(Thor: Love and Thunder)* (2022), the television film *[Guardians of the Galaxy Holiday Special](The)(The Guardians of the Galaxy Holiday Special)* (2022), and *[of the Galaxy Vol. 3](Guardians)(Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 3)* (2023).

### 2013–present: Breakthrough

Klementieff made her Hollywood debut in [Lee](Spike)(Spike Lee)'s *[Oldboy](Oldboy (2013 film))* (2013), a remake of the South Korean [of the same name](film)(Oldboy (2003 film)). She portrayed Haeng-bok, the bodyguard of the antagonist played by [Copley](Sharlto)(Sharlto Copley). A fan of the original film, Klementieff heard about the part through [Lee](Roy)(Roy Lee), a producer with the remake, and took boxing lessons after learning the role involved martial arts. After showcasing her boxing skills during her audition, Lee asked her to go home and come back wearing a more feminine outfit and make-up, like her character in the film. She contributed some of her own clothes to the character's wardrobe, and trained three hours a day for two months for an on-screen fight with star [Brolin](Josh)(Josh Brolin). Klementieff came up with the name Haeng-bok, Korean for "happiness", herself after Lee asked her to research possible names for the character.

Klementieff moved to Los Angeles after *Oldboy* was filmed and began pursuing more Hollywood auditions. She continued [taekwondo](taekwondo) after the film, and has a purple belt as of the summer of 2014. Her next acting role was the film ''Hacker's Game* (2015), in which she plays a hacker she compared to [Salander](Lisbeth)(Lisbeth Salander) from the novel *[Girl with the Dragon Tattoo](The)(The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo)''. Klementieff used her boxing skills again in the film, and due to the movie's low budget, she had to do her own make-up and choose her own wardrobe. It was her idea to dye her hair purple for the role, to which the directors first objected but later acquiesced. In 2017, she appeared in the romance drama *[Newness](Newness)* and the black comedy-drama *[Goes West](Ingrid)(Ingrid Goes West)*.

Klementieff received worldwide recognition when she joined the [Cinematic Universe](Marvel)(Marvel Cinematic Universe) as [Mantis](Mantis (Marvel Comics)), appearing in the films *[of the Galaxy Vol. 2](Guardians)(Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 2)* (2017), *[Infinity War](Avengers:)(Avengers: Infinity War)* (2018), and *[Endgame](Avengers:)(Avengers: Endgame)* (2019). In 2019, she appeared in an episode of the [Netflix](Netflix) science fiction anthology series *[Mirror](Black)(Black Mirror)*, the thriller film *[Gems](Uncut)(Uncut Gems)*, and had voice roles in the animated supernatural comedy film *[Addams Family](The)(The Addams Family (2019 film))*. In 2020, she had a recurring role as Martel in the [HBO](HBO) science fiction series *[Westworld](Westworld (TV series))*. She reprised her role as Mantis in the 2023 sequel *[of the Galaxy Vol. 3](Guardians)(Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 3)*, as well as appearing in the upcoming *[Impossible – Dead Reckoning Part One](Mission:)(Mission: Impossible – Dead Reckoning Part One)* and *[Impossible – Dead Reckoning Part Two](Mission:)(Mission: Impossible – Dead Reckoning Part Two)* in 2023 and 2024, respectively.
Pom Klementieff practices taekwondo and holds a purple belt in this martial art.

[{'section_id': 'playground_games:playground_games', 'section_name': 'Playground Games'}, {'section_id': 'playground_games:history', 'section_name': 'History'}, {'section_id': 'playground_games:games_developed', 'section_name': 'Games developed'}, {'section_id': 'playground_games:references', 'section_name': 'References'}, {'section_id': 'playground_games:external_links', 'section_name': 'External links'}]

## History

Playground Games was founded by Gavin Raeburn, Trevor Williams and Ralph Fulton; the studio was announced in November 2009, with its opening scheduled for early 2010. Playground Games announced their first project, *[Horizon](Forza)(Forza Horizon)*, in 2012. The title was developed in collaboration with [10 Studios](Turn)(Turn 10 Studios) and published by [Studios](Microsoft)(Microsoft Studios) for [360](Xbox)(Xbox 360) in October that year. The studio released *[Horizon 2](Forza)(Forza Horizon 2)* on Xbox 360 and [One](Xbox)(Xbox One) in September 2014, and *[Horizon 3](Forza)(Forza Horizon 3)* on Xbox One and [Windows](Microsoft)(Microsoft Windows) in September 2016.

In February 2014, Playground Games announced that they were forming a new development team focused on [game](mobile)(mobile game)s. In February 2017, the studio detailed plans to open a second studio, focusing on a non-racing open-world video game project. In November, they announced they had leased St. Albans House in Leamington Spa, which would provide the new studio with more than 17,000 square feet of office space. Expected headcounts for both studios were in excess of 200 people.

At [2018](E3)(E3 2018), [Microsoft](Microsoft) announced they had acquired Playground Games, which became part of Microsoft Studios (now known as Xbox Game Studios). At the same time, Microsoft Studios also announced *[Horizon 4](Forza)(Forza Horizon 4)*, which would be released on 2 October 2018, and that the studio was working on an unannounced AAA Open-World Action RPG project, later revealed to be in the *Fable* franchise.

In January 2022, it was reported that co-founder and [director](studio)(studio director) Gavin Raeburn left Playground Games to open his own studio, while [GM](General manager) Trevor Williams replaced him as studio head.
The three founders of Playground Games are Gavin Raeburn, Trevor Williams, and Ralph Fulton.

# List of largest cruise ships

*Revision ID: 1158022562 | Timestamp: 2023-06-01T13:42:21Z*

---

[[File:Wonder of the Seas - August 2021.png|thumb|right|*[of the Seas](Wonder)(Wonder of the Seas)* is the latest ship of Royal Caribbean's  of cruise ships.]]

[ship](Cruise)(Cruise ship)s are large [ship](passenger)(passenger ship)s used mainly for vacationing. Unlike [liner](ocean)(ocean liner)s, they typically embark on round-trip voyages to various ports-of-call, where passengers may go on [tours](Tourism) known as "shore excursions". They may carry thousands of passengers in a single trip, and are some of the largest ships in the world by the [tonnage](gross)(gross tonnage)(GT), bigger than many [ships](cargo)(List of largest container ships). Cruise ships started to exceed ocean liners in size and capacity in the mid-1990s; before then, few were more than 50,000GT. In the decades since, the size of the largest vessels has more than doubled. There have been nine or more new cruise ships added every year since 2001, most of which are 100,000GT or greater. In the two decades between 1988 and 2009, the largest cruise ships grew a third longer (268 m to 360 m), almost doubled their widths (32.2 m to 60.5 m), doubled the total passengers (2,744 to 5,400), and tripled in volume (73,000 GT to 225,000 GT). , the largest cruise ship, , has a gross tonnage of 236,857, is  long,  wide, and holds up to 6,988 passengers.

Cruise ships are organized much like floating hotels, with a complete hospitality staff in addition to the usual ship's crew. Modern cruise ships, while sacrificing some qualities of [seaworthiness](seakeeping), have added amenities to cater to [tourists](nautical)(nautical tourism), with recent vessels being described as "balcony-laden floating condominiums". The "megaships" went from a single deck with verandas to all decks with verandas, and feature ameneties such as theaters, fine-dining and chain restaurants, spas, fitness centers, casinos, sports facilities, and even amusement park attractions.

Cruise ships require electricity for powering both hotel services and for [propulsion](Marine propulsion). Cruise ships are designed with all the heavy machinery at the bottom of the ship and lightweight materials at the top, making them inherently stable even as ship designs are getting taller and taller, and most passenger ships utilize [fins](stabilizer)(Stabilizer (ship)) to further reduce rolling of tall ships in heavy weather. While some cruise ships use traditional fixed [propeller](propeller)s and [rudder](rudder)s to steer, most larger ships use propellers that can swivel left and right to steer the ship, known as [thruster](azimuth)(azimuth thruster)s, which allow even the largest ship designs to have adequate maneuverability.

Cruise ships are operated by [line](cruise)(cruise line)s, which are [companies](company) that market cruises to the public. In the 1990s, many cruise lines were bought by much larger holding companies and continue to operate as brands or subsidiaries of the holding company. For instance, [Corporation & plc](Carnival)(Carnival Corporation & plc) owns both the [mass-market](Mass market) [Cruise Line](Carnival)(Carnival Cruise Line), focused on larger party ships for younger travelers, and [America Line](Holland)(Holland America Line), whose smaller ships cultivate an image of classic elegance. The common practice in the cruise industry in ship sales and orders is to list the smaller operating company, not the larger holding corporation, as the recipient cruise line of the ship.
As of 2023, the largest cruise ship has a gross tonnage of 236,857 GT.

### Mentored by Balakirev; time with The Five

The Five}}

Once back in Saint Petersburg in May 1865, Rimsky-Korsakov's onshore duties consisted of a couple of hours of clerical duty each day, but he recalled that his desire to compose "had been stifled ... I did not concern myself with music at all."Rimsky-Korsakov, *My Musical Life*, p. 55. He wrote that contact with Balakirev in September 1865 encouraged him "to get accustomed to music and later to plunge into it".Rimsky-Korsakov, *My Musical Life*, p. 56. At Balakirev's suggestion, he wrote a trio to the [scherzo](scherzo) of the E-flat minor symphony, which it had lacked up to that point, and reorchestrated the entire symphony.Rimsky-Korsakov, *My Musical Life*, pp. 58–59. Its first performance came in December of that year under Balakirev's direction in Saint Petersburg.Abraham, *New Grove (1980)*, 16:28. A second performance followed in March 1866 under the direction of Konstantin Lyadov (father of composer [Lyadov](Anatoly)(Anatoly Lyadov)).

Correspondence between Rimsky-Korsakov and Balakirev clearly shows that some ideas for the symphony originated with Balakirev, who seldom stopped at merely correcting a piece of music, and would often recompose it at the piano. Rimsky-Korsakov recalled,

A pupil like myself had to submit to Balakirev a proposed composition in its embryo, say, even the first four or eight bars. Balakirev would immediately make corrections, indicating how to recast such an embryo; he would criticize it, would praise and extol the first two bars, but would censure the next two, ridicule them, and try hard to make the author disgusted with them. Vivacity of composition and fertility were not at all in favor, frequent recasting was demanded, and the composition was extended over a long period of time under the cold control of self-criticism.Rimsky-Korsakov, *My Musical Life*, p. 29.

[[File:Balakirev from 1914 Windsor Magazine.png|thumb|upright|alt=A man in his late 20s or early 30s with dark hair and a bushy beard, wearing a dark coat, dress shirt and tie|[Balakirev](Mily)(Mily Balakirev) encouraged Rimsky-Korsakov to continue composing.]]

Rimsky-Korsakov recalled that "Balakirev had no difficulty in getting along with me. At his suggestion I most readily rewrote the symphonic movements composed by me and brought them to completion with the help of his advice and improvisations".Rimsky-Korsakov, *My Musical Life*, p. 30. Though Rimsky-Korsakov later found Balakirev's influence stifling, and broke free from it,Maes, p. 44. this did not stop him in his memoirs from extolling the older composer's talents as a critic and improviser. Under Balakirev's mentoring, Rimsky-Korsakov turned to other compositions. He began a symphony in B minor, but felt it too closely followed [Beethoven](Ludwig van Beethoven)'s [Symphony](Ninth)(Symphony No. 9 (Beethoven)) and abandoned it. He completed an Overture on Three Russian Themes, based on Balakirev's folksong overtures, as well as a [on Serbian Themes](Fantasia)(Fantasy on Serbian Themes) that was performed at a concert given for the delegates of the [Congress](Slavonic)(Pan-Slavism) in 1867. In his review of this concert, nationalist critic [Stasov](Vladimir)(Vladimir Stasov) coined the phrase *Moguchaya kuchka* for the Balakirev circle (*Moguchaya kuchka* is usually translated as "The Mighty Handful" or "The Five"). Rimsky-Korsakov also composed the initial versions of *Sadko* and *[Antar](Antar (Rimsky-Korsakov))*, which cemented his reputation as a writer of orchestral works.

Rimsky-Korsakov socialized and discussed music with the other members of The Five; they critiqued one another's works in progress and collaborated on new pieces. He became friends with [Borodin](Alexander)(Alexander Borodin), whose music "astonished" him.Rimsky-Korsakov, *My Musical Life*, p. 57. He spent an increasing amount of time with Mussorgsky. Balakirev and Mussorgsky played piano four-hand music, Mussorgsky would sing, and they frequently discussed other composers' works, with preferred tastes running "toward Glinka, Schumann and Beethoven's late quartets".Rimsky-Korsakov, *My Musical Life*, p. 21. [Mendelssohn](Felix Mendelssohn) was not thought of highly, [Mozart](Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart) and [Haydn](Joseph Haydn) "were considered out of date and naïve", and [Bach](J.S.)(Johann Sebastian Bach) merely mathematical and unfeeling. Berlioz "was highly esteemed", Liszt "crippled and perverted from a musical point of view ... even a caricature", and Wagner discussed little. Rimsky-Korsakov "listened to these opinions with avidity and absorbed the tastes of Balakirev, Cui and Mussorgsky without reasoning or examination". Often, the musical works in question "were played before me only in fragments, and I had no idea of the whole work". This, he wrote, did not stop him from accepting these judgments at face value and repeating them "as if I were thoroughly convinced of their truth".

Rimsky-Korsakov became especially appreciated within The Five, and among those who visited the circle, for his talents as an orchestrator. He was asked by Balakirev to orchestrate a [Schubert](Franz Schubert) march for a concert in May 1868, by Cui to orchestrate the opening chorus of his opera *[Ratcliff](William)(William Ratcliff (Cui))* and by [Dargomyzhsky](Alexander)(Alexander Dargomyzhsky), whose works were greatly appreciated by The Five and who was close to death, to orchestrate his opera *[Stone Guest](The)(The Stone Guest (Dargomyzhsky))*.

In late 1871, Rimsky-Korsakov moved into Voin's former apartment, and invited Mussorgsky to be his roommate. The working arrangement they agreed upon was that Mussorgsky used the piano in the mornings while Rimsky-Korsakov worked on copying or orchestration. When Mussorgsky left for his civil service job at noon, Rimsky-Korsakov then used the piano. Time in the evenings was allotted by mutual agreement. "That autumn and winter the two of us accomplished a good deal", Rimsky-Korsakov wrote, "with constant exchange of ideas and plans. Mussorgsky composed and orchestrated the Polish act of *[Godunov](Boris)(Boris Godunov (opera))* and the folk scene 'Near Kromy.' I orchestrated and finished my *[of Pskov](Maid)(The Maid of Pskov)*."Rimsky-Korsakov, *My Musical Life*, p. 123.

### Orchestral works

The purely orchestral works fall into two categories. The best-known ones in the West, and perhaps the finest in overall quality, are mainly programmatic in nature — in other words, the musical content and how it is handled in the piece is determined by the plot or characters in a story, the action in a painting or events reported through another non-musical source. The second category of works is more academic, such as his First and Third Symphonies and his Sinfonietta. In these, Rimsky-Korsakov still employed folk themes but subjected them to abstract rules of musical composition.

[[File:RimskyScheherezadeThemes.png|thumb|left|alt=Two staves of music, one with a loud, forceful theme and the second with a softer, more undulating theme|Opening themes of the Sultan and [Scheherazade](Scheherazade (Rimsky-Korsakov))]]

Program music came naturally to Rimsky-Korsakov. To him, "even a folk theme has a program of sorts."Frolova-Walker, *New Grove (2001)*, 21:409. He composed the majority of his orchestral works in this genre at two periods of his career—at the beginning, with *Sadko* and *Antar* (also known as his Second Symphony, Op. 9), and in the 1880s, with *Scheherazade*, *Capriccio Espagnol* and the *Russian Easter Overture*. Despite the gap between these two periods, the composer's overall approach and the way he used his musical themes remained consistent. Both *Antar* and *Scheherazade* use a robust "Russian" theme to portray the male protagonists (the title character in *Antar*; the sultan in *Scheherazade*) and a more sinuous "Eastern" theme for the female ones (the [peri](peri) Gul-Nazar in *Antar* and the title character in *Scheherazade*).Maes, pp. 82, 175.

Where Rimsky-Korsakov changed between these two sets of works was in orchestration. While his pieces were always celebrated for their imaginative use of instrumental forces, the sparser textures of *Sadko* and *Antar* pale compared to the luxuriance of the more popular works of the 1880s. While a principle of highlighting "primary hues" of instrumental color remained in place, it was augmented in the later works by a sophisticated cachet of orchestral effects, some gleaned from other composers including Wagner, but many invented by himself.

As a result, these works resemble brightly colored mosaics, striking in their own right and often scored with a juxtaposition of pure orchestral groups. The final *tutti* of *Scheherazade* is a prime example of this scoring. The theme is assigned to trombones playing in unison, and is accompanied by a combination of [string](string instrument) patterns. Meanwhile, another pattern alternates with chromatic scales in the [woodwinds](woodwind instruments) and a third pattern of rhythms is played by percussion.Abraham, *New Grove (1980)*, 16:32–33.

Rimsky-Korsakov's non-program music, though well-crafted, does not rise to the same level of inspiration as his programmatic works; he needed fantasy to bring out the best in him. The First Symphony follows the outlines of Schumann's Fourth extremely closely, and is slighter in its thematic material than his later compositions. The Third Symphony and Sinfonietta each contain a series of variations on less-than-the-best music that can lead to tedium.
The Russian composer who was a member of the group known as The Five (also called "The Mighty Handful") and is famous for the orchestral suite Scheherazade is Nikolai Rimsky-Korsakov.

# Aldi

*Revision ID: 1158837261 | Timestamp: 2023-06-06T14:58:35Z*

---

(split in two parts in 1960, renamed to Aldi Nord and Aldi Süd in 1962)

| founders = [Karl](Karl Albrecht) and [Albrecht](Theo)(Theo Albrecht)

| location = [Essen](Essen), Germany (Aldi Nord) [Mülheim](Mülheim), Germany (Aldi Süd)

| locations = 11,235

| area_served = International

| homepage =

}}

**Aldi** (stylised as **ALDI**) is the common company brand name of two German multinational family-owned [supermarket](discount)(discount supermarket) [chains](Chain store) operating over 10,000 stores in 20 countries. The chain was founded by brothers [Karl](Karl Albrecht) and [Albrecht](Theo)(Theo Albrecht) in 1946, when they took over their mother's store in [Essen](Essen). The business was split into two separate groups in 1960, that later became **Aldi Nord**, headquartered in [Essen](Essen), and **Aldi Süd**, headquartered in [Mülheim](Mülheim an der Ruhr)."[Impressum](http://www.aldi-nord.de/impressum.html)" Aldi Nord. Retrieved on 14 February 2011. "Aldi Einkauf GmbH & Co. oHG Eckenbergstraße 16 45307 Essen.""[Impressum](http://www.aldi-sud.de/de/html/impressum.htm) ." Aldi Süd. Retrieved on 14 February 2011. "Burgstraße 37 45476 Mülheim an der Ruhr Amtsgericht Duisburg HRA 8577."

In 1962, they introduced the name **Aldi** (a [abbreviation](syllabic)(syllabic abbreviation) for **Al**brecht **Di**skont), which is pronounced . In Germany, Aldi Nord and Aldi Süd have been financially and legally separate since 1966, although both divisions' names may appear as if they were a single enterprise with certain [brand](store)(store brand)s or when negotiating with [contractor](General contractor) companies. The formal business name of Aldi Nord is Aldi Einkauf GmbH & Co., while the formal business name of Aldi Süd is ALDI SÜD Dienstleistungs-SE & Co.  Each company is owned and operated independently, but do have contractual business with one another.

Aldi's German operations consist of Aldi Nord's 35 individual regional companies with about 2,500 stores in western, northern, and eastern Germany, and Aldi Süd's 32 regional companies with 1,900 stores in western and southern Germany. How Does Aldi Make Money  Strategy and Insights – Vizologi  rethinking business model design|date=13 December 2017|work=Vizologi  rethinking business model design|access-date=5 July 2018}} Internationally, Aldi Nord operates in [Denmark](Denmark), [France](France), the [Benelux](Benelux) countries, [Portugal](Portugal), [Spain](Spain) and [Poland](Poland), while Aldi Süd operates in [Ireland](Republic of Ireland), the [Kingdom](United)(United Kingdom), [Hungary](Hungary), [Switzerland](Switzerland), [Australia](Australia), [China](China), [Italy](Italy), [Austria](Austria) and [Slovenia](Slovenia). Both Aldi Nord (owner of [Joe's](Trader)(Trader Joe's)) and Aldi Süd (as Aldi) also operate in the [States](United)(United States) with 1,600 stores between them as of 2017, and the U.S. is the only country to have both Aldi companies operating outside of Germany.
The name "Aldi" in German stands for "Albrecht Diskont." It is a syllabic abbreviation combining "Albrecht," the surname of the founders, and "Diskont," which means "discount."

### Background

After the success of [Nintendo](Nintendo)'s [Boy family](Game)(Game Boy family) of [game console](handheld)(handheld game console)s throughout the 1990s and early 2000s, with little market competition, and [Sony](Sony)'s massive success with its [PlayStation](PlayStation (console)) and [2](PlayStation)(PlayStation 2) [video game console](home)(home video game console)s around the same time, Sony entered the handheld market as well. In 2004, it released the [Portable](PlayStation)(PlayStation Portable) (PSP) to compete with the [DS](Nintendo)(Nintendo DS) as part of the [generation of video game consoles](seventh)(seventh generation of video game consoles). After a slow start in the worldwide market, it was invigorated in Japan with multiple releases in the *[Hunter](Monster)(Monster Hunter)* series. With the series being less popular in western regions, it failed to revive the platform in the same way. The PSP ended up being a mixed result for the company. It was seen as a success in that it was the only handheld video game platform that had ever significantly competed with Nintendo for market share, with almost 80 million units sold in its lifespan, roughly the same amount as Nintendo's [Boy Advance](Game)(Game Boy Advance) had during the [generation of video game consoles](sixth)(sixth generation of video game consoles). This is only a little more than half of the sales of its actual market competitor, the DS, which was more than 150 million units by the end of 2011.

Rumors of a successor to the PSP came as early as July 2009 when *[Eurogamer](Eurogamer)* reported that Sony was working on such a device, which would utilize the PowerVR SGX543MP processor and perform at a level similar to the original [Xbox](Xbox (console)). Through mid-2010, websites continued to run stories about accounts of the existence of a "PSP 2". Reports arose during the [Game Show](Tokyo)(Tokyo Game Show) that the device was unveiled internally during a private meeting during mid-September held at Sony Computer Entertainment's headquarters in Aoyama, Tokyo. Shortly after, reports of [kits](development)(development kits) for the handheld had reportedly already been shipped to numerous video game developers including both [first-party](SIE Worldwide Studios) and third-party developers to start making games for the device, a report later confirmed by *[Kombat](Mortal)(Mortal Kombat (2011 video game))* Executive Producer Shaun Himmerick. By November, Senior Vice President of [Arts](Electronic)(Electronic Arts), Patrick Soderlund, confirmed that he had seen that the PlayStation Portable successor existed, but could not confirm details. In the same month, [VG247](VG247) released pictures of an early prototype version showing a [Go](PSP)(PSP Go)-like slide-screen design along with two analog sticks, two cameras and a microphone, though the report mentioned that overheating issues had since caused them to move away from the design in favor of a model more similar to the original PlayStation Portable device.

Throughout 2010, Sony would not confirm these reports of a PSP successor but would make comments regarding making future hardware. [Yoshida](Shuhei)(Shuhei Yoshida), President of [Worldwide Studios](SCE)(SCE Worldwide Studios) revealed that his studio, despite usually being more involved with software, had a continued role in future hardware development at the time. In December, [Computer Entertainment](Sony)(Sony Computer Entertainment) CEO [Hirai](Kazuo)(Kazuo Hirai) stated that Sony aimed to appeal to a wide demographic of people by using multiple input methods on future hardware; buttons and joysticks for traditional handheld game system users, and touchscreens for [phone](smart)(smart phone) users. The device was officially announced by Sony on January 27, 2011, at their "PlayStation Meeting" press conference held by the company in Japan. The system, only known by its code name "Next Generation Portable", was announced to be a handheld gaming device that aimed for [3](PlayStation)(PlayStation 3) quality visuals, which was later clarified to not be taken at a literal level because, according to David Coombes, platform research manager at [Computer Entertainment America](Sony)(Sony Computer Entertainment America), "Well, it's not going to run at 2 GHz [the PS3](like) because the battery would last five minutes and it would probably set fire to your pants". Its power was later described by Sony engineers as about halfway between the PSP and PS3. As rumors had suggested, the device was designed to present "the best of both worlds" between mobile and handheld gaming, including a 5-inch OLED touchscreen, a rear touchpad coupled with physical buttons and dual analog sticks. Sony also revealed that the device would be using a mix of retail and digital distribution of games. Further details were announced at [Developers Conference](Game)(Game Developers Conference) 2011, including that Sony would be dropping the PSP's [UMD](Universal Media Disc) disc format in favor of small game cartridges of 2 GB or 4 GB size variants.  along with two cameras, facial detection, head detection and tracking capabilities.
The codename used for the PlayStation Vita before its official announcement was "Next Generation Portable" (NGP).

## Cast

* [Maguire](Tobey)(Tobey Maguire) as [Parker / Spider-Man](Peter)(Peter Parker (Sam Raimi film series)):A superhero, [University](Columbia)(Columbia University) physics student, and photographer for the *Daily Bugle*. Juggling these separate lives means he briefly gives up his responsibilities as a superhero in a moment of adversity.

* [Dunst](Kirsten)(Kirsten Dunst) as [Jane Watson](Mary)(Mary Jane Watson (Sam Raimi film series)): An aspiring [Broadway](Broadway theatre) actress and a friend Peter has loved since he was a child, yet he gave up the chance of being with her out of concern for her safety. Still harboring feelings for Peter, Mary Jane begins dating [Jameson](John)(John Jameson (comics)) and eventually becomes engaged to him, in an effort to make Peter jealous. She also has a crush on Spider-Man, who saved her life numerous times in the past, and is unaware that the hero and Peter are one and the same.

* [Franco](James)(James Franco) as [Osborn](Harry)(Harry Osborn (Sam Raimi film series)): [Oscorp](Oscorp)'s current [CEO](Chief executive officer), Norman Osborn's son and Peter's best friend, who holds his alter-ego Spider-Man responsible for his father's death. He is also Mary Jane's ex-boyfriend and still harbors feelings for her.

* [Molina](Alfred)(Alfred Molina) as [Otto Octavius / Doctor Octopus](Dr.)(Otto Octavius (film character)):A scientist working on behalf of [Oscorp](Oscorp) and Peter's role model and mentor who goes insane after his failure to create a self-sustaining fusion reaction, which also resulted in the death of his wife, Rosie. Octavius is bonded with his handling equipment, four artificially intelligent mechanical tentacles, which influence his mentality and convince him that he must finish his experiment at all costs.

* [Harris](Rosemary)(Rosemary Harris) as [Parker](May)(Aunt May): [Parker](Ben)(Uncle Ben)'s widow and Peter's aunt. villain |last=Hiatt |first=Brian |magazine=[Weekly](Entertainment)(Entertainment Weekly) |date=July 21, 2003 |access-date=December 22, 2020 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200817202919/https://ew.com/article/2003/07/21/first-look-doc-ock-spider-man-2s-villain/ |archive-date=August 17, 2020 |url-status=live}}

* [Murphy](Donna)(Donna Murphy) as Rosie Octavius: Otto's wife and assistant.

[K. Simmons](J.)(J. K. Simmons) reprises his role as [Jonah Jameson](J.)(J. Jonah Jameson (film character)), the miserly manager and editor-in-chief of the *Daily Bugle*, while [Gillies](Daniel)(Daniel Gillies) portrays his son [Jameson](John)(John Jameson (comics)), an astronaut and Mary Jane's fiancé. [Estabrook](Christine)(Christine Estabrook) appears briefly as Jameson's wife and John's mother.

As with the previous film, [Campbell](Bruce)(Bruce Campbell) has a [appearance](cameo)(cameo appearance), this time as an usher who refuses Peter entry for arriving late to Mary Jane Watson's show. *Spider-Man* co-creator [Lee](Stan)(Stan Lee) portrays a man on the street who saves a woman from falling debris during a battle between Spider-Man and Doctor Octopus. [Baker](Dylan)(Dylan Baker) portrays [Curt Connors](Dr.)(Lizard (comics)), one of Peter's college physics professors and a colleague of Octavius, while [Dafoe](Willem)(Willem Dafoe) reprises his role as [Osborn](Norman)(Norman Osborn (Sam Raimi film series)), Harry's deceased father who appears to him as a hallucination. Dafoe came up with the idea during promotion for *[Spider-Man](Spider-Man (2002 film))*, which he compared to [Hamlet](King)(Ghost (Hamlet)) haunting his son to avenge him. [Banks](Elizabeth)(Elizabeth Banks), John Paxton, [Raimi](Ted)(Ted Raimi) and [Nunn](Bill)(Bill Nunn) reprise their roles as [Brant](Betty)(Betty Brant), Osborn family butler Bernard Houseman, Ted Hoffman, and [Robertson](Robbie)(Robbie Robertson (comics)), respectively. Bill Nunn |last=Hughes |first=William |website=[A.V. Club](The)(The A.V. Club) |date=September 24, 2016 |access-date=December 22, 2020 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20191208202929/https://news.avclub.com/r-i-p-do-the-right-thing-and-spider-man-s-bill-nunn-1798252282 |archive-date=December 8, 2019 |url-status=live}} [Baskin](Elya)(Elya Baskin) portrays Mr. Ditkovitch, Peter's landlord, (whose name is a reference to *Spider-Man* co-creator [Ditko](Steve)(Steve Ditko)) and [Tovah](Mageina)(Mageina Tovah) plays his daughter Ursula. [Robertson](Cliff)(Cliff Robertson) reprises his role as Peter's uncle [Parker](Ben)(Uncle Ben) in a [flashback](flashback (narrative)).

[Spiegel](Scott)(Scott Spiegel) portrays a man who attempts to eat some pizza Spider-Man is delivering, only to have it webbed from his hands. Elyse Dinh portrays a violinist. [McHale](Joel)(Joel McHale) portrays Mr. Jacks, a bank teller. [Sparks](Hal)(Hal Sparks) portrays an [elevator](elevator) passenger who has a conversation with Spider-Man. [Rawlings](Donnell)(Donnell Rawlings) portrays the New Yorker who exclaims that Spider-Man "stole that guy's pizzas" and [Deschanel](Emily)(Emily Deschanel) portrays a receptionist. [Briscoe](Brent)(Brent Briscoe) plays the garbage man who finds Spider-Man's costume in the trash and gives it to Jameson. [McRobbie](Peter)(Peter McRobbie) plays an OsCorp representative. [Diamond](Reed)(Reed Diamond) plays Algernon. [List](Peyton)(Peyton List (actress, born 1998)) and her brother [List](Spencer)(Spencer List) make their film debuts playing a little girl and boy playing on steps respectively. Booking Agent|website=MN2S|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201231215504/https://mn2s.com/booking-agency/talent-roster/spencer-list/|archive-date=December 31, 2020|url-status=live|access-date=December 31, 2020}} [Dae Kim](Daniel)(Daniel Dae Kim) plays Raymond, an assistant of Otto Octavius working in his laboratory. [Mandvi](Aasif)(Aasif Mandvi) portrays Mr. Aziz, the owner of [Pizza](Joe's)(Joe's Pizza). [Diaz](Joey)(Joey Diaz), [Hicks](Dan)(Dan Hicks (actor)) and [Dykstra](Chloe)(Chloe Dykstra) portray train passengers. [Ferlito](Vanessa)(Vanessa Ferlito) portrays Louise, one of Mary Jane's co-stars. [Bryant](Joy)(Joy Bryant) appears as a spectator that witnesses Spider-Man in action. [Landis](John)(John Landis) plays one of the doctors who operate on Doctor Octopus. [LaMarr](Phil)(Phil LaMarr) portrays a train passenger who is most easily seen to the left of Spider-Man (the viewer's right) while the hero uses webbing to slow the train down. [Edelman](Gregg)(Gregg Edelman) portrays Dr. Davis.

### Film

* In an early script for [Cannon](The Cannon Group, Inc.)'s aborted Spider-Man film from, written by Ted Newsom and [Brancato](John)(John Brancato), Otto Octavius was rewritten to become a teacher and mentor to a college-aged Peter Parker. The cyclotron accident which "creates" Spider-Man also deforms the scientist into Doctor Octopus and results in his mad pursuit of proof of the Fifth Force. "Doc Ock" reconstructs his cyclotron and causes electromagnetic abnormalities, anti-gravity effects, and bi-location, which threatens to engulf New York City and the world. Additionally, [Hoskins](Bob)(Bob Hoskins) and [Schwarzenegger](Arnold)(Arnold Schwarzenegger) were considered for the role.https://thescriptsavant.com/pdf/SpiderMan.pdf

* Director [Raimi](Sam)(Sam Raimi) has stated that Doctor Octopus was intended to appear in *[Spider-Man](Spider-Man (2002 film))* (2002) and team up with the [Goblin](Green)(Norman Osborn (Sam Raimi film series)), but was not included because Raimi thought it "wouldn't do the movie justice to have a third origin in there".

* Otto Octavius / Doctor Octopus appears in the [Sony](Sony) film *[2](Spider-Man)(Spider-Man 2)* (2004), portrayed by [Molina](Alfred)(Alfred Molina). This version is a sympathetic, but misguided individual, and the husband and lab partner of Rosie Octavius (portrayed by [Murphy](Donna)(Donna Murphy)). Initially a well-meaning scientist working with [Oscorp](Oscorp) to develop a form of self-sustainable energy to benefit mankind, Octavius turns to villainy after his experiment goes wrong, resulting in Rosie's death and Octavius losing control of his tentacle harness' [intelligence](artificial)(artificial intelligence), which begins to influence his mind and actions and brings him into conflict with [Spider-Man](Peter Parker (Sam Raimi film series)). With the web-slinger's help, Octavius eventually sees the error of his ways and sacrifices himself to sink a fusion reactor he built into the [River](East)(East River), where he drowns.

** Octavius appears in the [Cinematic Universe](Marvel)(Marvel Cinematic Universe) (MCU) film *[No Way Home](Spider-Man:)(Spider-Man: No Way Home)*, portrayed again by Alfred Molina. In April 2021, Molina said it was "wonderful" to play the character again. Additionally, he was [de-aged](digitally)(De-aging in film) in the film to resemble how he appeared in 2004, despite his concerns about his fighting style not looking realistic due to his age. Prior to his death, Octavius is transported to an alternate universe due to a magic spell gone wrong and receives a cure from an alternate universe version of [Spider-Man](Peter Parker (Marvel Cinematic Universe)) before being returned to his native universe.

* A female incarnation of Doctor Octopus named **Dr. Olivia "Liv" Octavius** appears in *[Into the Spider-Verse](Spider-Man:)(Spider-Man: Into the Spider-Verse)*, voiced by [Hahn](Kathryn)(Kathryn Hahn). She is the head scientist of [Alchemax](Alchemax) and the [Kingpin](Kingpin (character))'s right-hand woman who sports a large [hairstyle](beehive)(Beehive (hairstyle)), glasses with octagonal lenses, and [pneumatic](pneumatic) tentacles tipped with claws. Under the Kingpin's orders, she builds a [super-collider](particle accelerator) to access parallel universes. In spite of the initial tests nearly destroying New York City and bringing several [reality versions of Spider-Man](alternate)(Alternative versions of Spider-Man) to their universe, the Kingpin orders Liv to continue working on the collider. She later encounters [Morales](Miles)(Miles Morales) and an alternate reality Peter Parker while they are infiltrating Alchemax, but fails to catch them. After confronting the assembled Spider-People at [Parker](May)(Aunt May)'s house alongside the Kingpin and his other henchmen and failing to stop them a second time, Liv tries to stop the heroes at the collider, only to be hit by a truck when the machine goes haywire and melds her universe with aspects of others.

** Additionally, a Doctor Octopus from [Stacy](Gwen)(Spider-Woman (Gwen Stacy))'s universe makes a non-speaking [appearance](cameo)(cameo appearance) in a flashback.

* Otto Octavius as the Superior Spider-Man makes a non-speaking appearance in *[Across the Spider-Verse](Spider-Man:)(Spider-Man: Across the Spider-Verse)* as a member of [2099](Spider-Man)(Spider-Man 2099)'s Spider-Society. Additionally, Liv Octavius makes cameo appearances in flashbacks, voiced by archival audio of Kathryn Hahn, while a comic book-accurate Doctor Octopus additionally appears as a dimension-displaced prisoner of the Spider-Society, voiced by archival audio of Alfred Molina.

Alfred Molina portrayed Otto Octavius, also known as Doctor Octopus (Doc Ock), in Sam Raimi's Spider-Man 2. Doctor Octopus is a scientist and the film's main antagonist who, after a failed experiment, becomes bonded with four mechanical tentacles and opposes Spider-Man.

# Unicursal hexagram

*Revision ID: 1154828308 | Timestamp: 2023-05-14T22:37:52Z*

---

[[unicursal hexagram.svg|upright|thumb|Non-interlaced unicursal hexagram](File:Solid)]

The **unicursal hexagram** is a [hexagram](hexagram) or six-pointed star that can be traced or drawn [unicursally](unicursal curve), in one continuous line rather than by two overlaid triangles. The hexagram can also be depicted inside a circle with the points touching it. It is often depicted in an interlaced form with the lines of the hexagram passing over and under one another to form a [knot](knot (mathematics)). It is a specific instance of the far more general shape discussed in [Pascal](Blaise)(Blaise Pascal)'s 1639 *[Mysticum](Hexagrammum)(Hexagrammum Mysticum)*.

The unicursal hexagram is an example of the general shape discussed in Blaise Pascal's 1639 work, "Hexagrammum Mysticum." In that work, Pascal explored geometric properties related to the hexagram, and the unicursal hexagram is a specific instance of those ideas.

### Contemporary regulations

[[sign warning about the presence of bears. The Norwegian text translates into "Applies to all of Svalbard".](File:Polar-Bear-Warning-Longyearbyen.jpg|thumb|right|Road)]

Concerns over the future survival of the species led to the development of national regulations on polar bear hunting, beginning in the mid-1950s. The Soviet Union banned all hunting in 1956. Canada began imposing hunting quotas in 1968. Norway passed a series of increasingly strict regulations from 1965 to 1973, and has completely banned hunting since then. The United States began regulating hunting in 1971 and adopted the [Mammal Protection Act](Marine)(Marine Mammal Protection Act of 1972) in 1972. In 1973, the [Agreement on the Conservation of Polar Bears](International)(International Agreement on the Conservation of Polar Bears) was signed by all five nations whose territory is inhabited by polar bears: Canada, Denmark, Norway, the [Union](Soviet)(Soviet Union), and the United States. Member countries agreed to place restrictions on recreational and commercial hunting, ban hunting from aircraft and icebreakers, and conduct further research.[International Agreement on the Conservation of Polar Bears](https://web.archive.org/web/20030409113042/http://pbsg.npolar.no/ConvAgree/agreement.htm), 15 November 1973, Oslo The treaty allows hunting "by local people using traditional methods". Norway is the only country of the five in which all harvest of polar bears is banned. The agreement was a rare case of international cooperation during the [War](Cold)(Cold War). Biologist [Stirling](Ian)(Ian Stirling (biologist)) commented, "For many years, the conservation of polar bears was the only subject in the entire Arctic that nations from both sides of the Iron Curtain could agree upon sufficiently to sign an agreement. Such was the intensity of human fascination with this magnificent predator, the only marine bear."[Ian](Stirling,)(Ian Stirling (biologist)) *Foreword* in

Agreements have been made between countries to co-manage their shared polar bear subpopulations. After several years of negotiations, Russia and the United States signed an agreement in October 2000 to jointly set quotas for indigenous subsistence hunting in Alaska and [Chukotka](Chukotka Autonomous Okrug). The treaty was ratified in October 2007. In September 2015, the polar bear range states agreed upon a "circumpolar action plan" describing their conservation strategy for polar bears.

The species is listed in Appendix II of the [on International Trade in Endangered Species](Convention)(Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species) (CITES) meaning international trade, including in parts or derivatives, is controlled by the CITES system of permits and certificates. The United States government has proposed that polar bears be transferred to Appendix I of [CITES](CITES) which would ban all commercial international trade in polar bear parts. The decision to leave the species listed under Appendix II was endorsed by the IUCN and [TRAFFIC](TRAFFIC), who determined that such an uplisting was unlikely to confer a conservation benefit.

The five nations that are signatories of the Agreement on the Conservation of Polar Bears are:

1. Canada
2. Denmark
3. Norway
4. Soviet Union (now Russia)
5. United States

These are the five countries whose territory is inhabited by polar bears.

### Later life

[[File:Miyamoto Musashi Self-Portrait.jpg|thumb|upright|Miyamoto Musashi, *[Self-portrait](Self-portrait),* c. 1640]]Twenty-one years later, in 1633, Musashi began staying with [Tadatoshi](Hosokawa)(Hosokawa Tadatoshi), *[daimyō](Daimyo)* of [Castle](Kumamoto)(Kumamoto Castle), who had moved to the [Kumamoto](Kumamoto) fief and Kokura, to train and paint. While he engaged in very few duels; one would occur in 1634 at the arrangement of Lord Ogasawara, in which Musashi defeated a lance specialist by the name of [Matabei](Takada)(Takada Matabei). Musashi would officially become the retainer of the Hosokowa lords of Kumamoto in 1640. The *Niten Ki* records "[he] received from Lord Tadatoshi: 17 retainers, a stipend of 300 [koku](koku), the rank of *ōkumigashira* 大組頭, and [Castle](Chiba)(Chiba Castle) in Kumamoto as his residence."Toyota, p. 250

[[File:Tombe de Miyamoto Musashi à Ōhara, province de Mimasaka.jpg|thumb|Miyamoto Musashi's grave in [Ōhara-chō](Ōhara, Okayama), [of Mimasaka](province)(Mimasaka Province)]]

[[park.JPG|thumb|upright|The grave-marker of Miyamoto Musashi, in present-day Kumamoto Prefecture (熊本県)](File:Musashizuka)]

[[File:Miyamoto_Musashi_killing_a_giant_nue.jpg|thumb|Miyamoto Musashi kills a shark fish (Yamazame) in the mountains across the border of [Province](Echizen)(Echizen Province), by [Kuniyoshi](Utagawa)(Utagawa Kuniyoshi)]]

[[File:Musashi_ts_pic.jpg|thumb|Miyamoto Musashi in his prime, wielding two [bokken](bokken); woodblock print by [Kuniyoshi](Utagawa)(Utagawa Kuniyoshi)]]

In the second month of 1641, Musashi wrote a work called the *Hyoho Sanju Go* ("Thirty-five Instructions on Strategy") for [Tadatoshi](Hosokawa)(Hosokawa Tadatoshi). This work overlapped and formed the basis for the later *[Book of Five Rings](The)(The Book of Five Rings)*. This was the year that his adopted son, [Yoemon](Hirao)(Hirao Yoemon), became Master of Arms for the Owari fief. In 1642, Musashi suffered attacks of [neuralgia](neuralgia), foreshadowing his future ill-health. In 1643 he retired to a cave named *[Reigandō](Reigandō)* as a hermit to write *[Book of Five Rings](The)(The Book of Five Rings)*. He finished it in the second month of 1645. On the twelfth of the fifth month, sensing his impending death, Musashi bequeathed his worldly possessions, after giving his manuscript copy of *The Book of Five Rings* to the younger brother of Terao Magonojo, his closest disciple. He died in Reigandō cave around June 13, 1645 (*[Shōhō](Shōhō) 2, 19th day of the 5th month*). The *Hyoho senshi denki* described his passing:

Miyamoto Musashi died of what is believed to be [cancer](thoracic)(lung cancer). He died peacefully after finishing the text *[Dokkōdō](Dokkōdō)* ("The Way of Walking Alone", or "The Way of Self-Reliance"), 21 precepts on self-discipline to guide future generations.

Miyamoto Musashi is believed to have died of cancer, specifically lung cancer, in 1645. He passed away peacefully in the Reigandō cave after completing his final work, Dokkōdō ("The Way of Walking Alone").

## Ships

[[File:Ships in Bombay Harbour, 1731.jpg|thumb|right|Ships in [Harbour](Bombay)(Bombay Harbour), c. 1731]]

Ships of the East India Company were called [Indiamen](East)(East Indiaman) or simply "Indiamen".Sutton, Jean (1981) *Lords of the East: The East India Company and Its Ships*. London: Conway Maritime Their names were sometimes prefixed with the initials "HCS", standing for "Honourable Company's Service" or "Honourable Company's Ship", such as  and .

[[Royal George.jpg|thumb|right| was one of the five East Indiamen the Spanish fleet captured in 1780](File:Indiaman)]

During the [Revolutionary](French)(French Revolutionary Wars) and [Wars](Napoleonic)(Napoleonic Wars), the East India Company arranged for [of marque](letters)(Letter of marque) for its vessels such as *Lord Nelson*. This was not so that they could carry cannon to fend off warships, privateers, and pirates on their voyages to India and China (that they could do without permission) but so that, should they have the opportunity to take a prize, they could do so without being guilty of piracy. Similarly, the *Earl of Mornington*, an East India Company [ship](packet)(packet ship) of only six guns, also sailed under a letter of marque.

In addition, the company had its own navy, the [Marine](Bombay)(History of the Indian Navy), equipped with warships such as . These vessels often accompanied vessels of the Royal Navy on expeditions, such as the [of Java](Invasion)(Invasion of Java (1811)).

At the [of Pulo Aura](Battle)(Battle of Pulo Aura), which was probably the company's most notable naval victory, [Dance](Nathaniel)(Nathaniel Dance), Commodore of a convoy of Indiamen and sailing aboard the , led several Indiamen in a skirmish with a French squadron, driving them off. Some six years earlier, on 28 January 1797, five Indiamen, *Woodford*, under Captain Charles Lennox, *Taunton-Castle*, Captain Edward Studd, *Canton*, Captain Abel Vyvyan, *Boddam*, Captain George Palmer, and , Captain John Christian Lochner, had encountered Admiral [Sercey](de)(Pierre César Charles de Sercey) and his squadron of frigates. On this occasion the Indiamen succeeded in bluffing their way to safety, and without any shots even being fired. Lastly, on 15 June 1795, *General Goddard* played a large role in the capture of seven Dutch East Indiamen off [Helena](St)(Saint Helena).

[Indiamen](East)(East Indiamen) were large and strongly built and when the [Navy](Royal)(Royal Navy) was desperate for vessels to escort merchant convoys it bought several of them to convert to warships. *Earl of Mornington* became HMS *Drake*. Other examples include:

*

*

*  (1795)

*  (1804)

*

*

Their design as merchant vessels meant that their performance in the warship role was underwhelming and the Navy converted them to transports.

The East India Company's ships were commonly called "Indiamen" or "East Indiamen." Sometimes, their names were prefixed with "HCS," standing for "Honourable Company's Service" or "Honourable Company's Ship."

## Etymology

[[van Strij - Het Jacht van de kamer Rotterdam.jpg|thumb|An 18th-century Dutch *jacht*](File:Jacob)]

The term, *yacht*, originates from the [Dutch](Dutch language) word *jacht* (pl. *jachten*, which means "hunt"), and originally referred to light, fast sailing vessels that the [Republic](Dutch)(Dutch Republic) navy used to pursue [pirate](pirate)s and other transgressors around and into the shallow waters of the [Countries](Low)(Low Countries).

The word "yacht" originates from the Dutch word "jacht" (plural: jachten), which means "hunt." It originally referred to light, fast sailing vessels used by the Dutch navy to pursue pirates and other transgressors in the shallow waters of the Low Countries.

## Filmography

# Mamoudou Athie

*Revision ID: 1159518237 | Timestamp: 2023-06-10T21:09:59Z*

---

| birth_place        = [Mauritania](Mauritania)

| education          = [Esper Studio](William)(William Esper Studio)[University](Yale)(Yale University) ([MFA](Master of Fine Arts))

| occupation         = Actor

| years_active       = 2012–present

}}

**Mamoudou Athie** ( ; born July 25, 1988) is a Mauritanian-American actor. He is best known for starring in the 2022 [Netflix](Netflix) horror series *[81](Archive)(Archive 81)* and supporting roles in films including [World: Dominion*](*Jurassic)(Jurassic World Dominion) (2022).

Athie began his career in theater—making his [debut](Broadway)(Broadway debut) in 2015—and subsequently had supporting roles in films like *[Cake$](Patti)(Patti Cake$)* (2017), *[Circle](The)(The Circle (2017 film))* (2017), *[Store](Unicorn)(Unicorn Store)* (2017), *[Front Runner](The)(The Front Runner (film))* (2018), and *[Underwater](Underwater (film))* (2020), and in the television series *[Get Down](The)(The Get Down)* (2016–2017), [Detour*](*The)(The Detour (TV series)) (2017), *[for Your Loss](Sorry)(Sorry for Your Loss)* (2018–2019), and the [FXX](FXX) anthology [*Cake*](Cake (2019 TV series)) (2019). He had first feature film starring roles in 2020, starring in Netflix's [*Uncorked*](Uncorked (2020 film)) and Amazon's [Box*](*Black)(Black Box (2020 film)).

Athie was nominated for [Emmy Award for Outstanding Actor in a Short Form Comedy or Drama Series](Primetime)(Primetime Emmy Award for Outstanding Actor in a Short Form Comedy or Drama Series) for his performance in *Cake*.
Mamoudou Athie starred in the 2022 Netflix horror series "Archive 81."

## Military career

### Political crisis in Scotland

[[edinburghcastle.jpg|thumb|left|Statue of Wallace at Edinburgh Castle](File:Braveheart)]

When Wallace was growing up, King [III](Alexander)(Alexander III of Scotland) ruled Scotland. His reign had seen a period of peace and economic stability. On 19 March 1286, however, Alexander died after falling from his horse.Traquair p. 15 The heir to the throne was Alexander's granddaughter, [Maid of Norway](Margaret,)(Margaret, Maid of Norway). As she was still a child and in Norway, the Scottish lords set up a government of guardians. Margaret fell ill on the voyage to Scotland and died in Orkney in late September 1290. The lack of a clear heir led to a period known as the "Great Cause", with a total of thirteen contenders laying claim to the throne. The most credible claims were [Balliol](John)(John Balliol) and [Bruce](Robert)(Robert Bruce, 5th Lord of Annandale), grandfather of the future king [the Bruce](Robert)(Robert the Bruce).Traquair pp. 23–35

With Scotland threatening to descend into civil war, King [I of England](Edward)(Edward I of England) was invited in by the Scottish nobility to arbitrate. Before the process could begin, he insisted that all of the contenders recognise him as [Paramount of Scotland](Lord)(Lord Paramount of Scotland). In early November 1292, at a great feudal court held in the castle at [Berwick-upon-Tweed](Berwick-upon-Tweed), judgment was given in favour of [Balliol](John)(John Balliol) having the strongest claim in law based on being senior in genealogical [primogeniture](primogeniture) even though not in [of blood](proximity)(proximity of blood).

Edward proceeded to take steps to progressively undermine John's authority, treating [Scotland](Scotland) as a feudal vassal state, demanding [homage](Homage (feudal)) be paid towards himself and military support in his war against France — even summoning King John Balliol to stand before the English court as a common plaintiff. The Scots soon tired of their deeply compromised king, and the direction of affairs was allegedly taken out of his hands by the leading men of the kingdom, who appointed a Council of Twelve—in practice, a new panel of Guardians—at [Stirling](Stirling) in July 1295. They went on to conclude a treaty of mutual assistance with France—known in later years as the [Alliance](Auld)(Auld Alliance).

In retaliation for Scotland's treaty with France, Edward I invaded, storming Berwick-upon-Tweed and commencing the [of Scottish Independence](Wars)(Wars of Scottish Independence). The Scots were defeated at [Dunbar](Battle of Dunbar (1296)) and the English took [Castle](Dunbar)(Dunbar Castle) on 27 April 1296. Edward forced John to abdicate, which he did at [Stracathro](Stracathro) near [Montrose](Montrose, Angus) on 10 July 1296.Dunbar, Sir Archibald H., Bt., *Scottish Kings – A Revised Chronology of Scottish History 1005–1625*, Edinburgh, 1899: p. 116 Here the arms of Scotland were formally torn from John's surcoat, giving him the abiding name of "Toom Tabard" (empty coat). By July, Edward had instructed his officers to receive formal homage from some 1,800 Scottish nobles (many of the rest being prisoners of war at that time).Traquair pp. 15–59

### Start of the uprising

[[File:William Wallace statue, Scottish National Portrait Gallery, Edinburgh.JPG|thumb|upright|Wallace statue by D. W. Stevenson on the Scottish National Portrait Gallery, [Edinburgh](Edinburgh)]]

The first act definitely known to have been carried out by Wallace was his [of William de Heselrig](killing)(Action at Lanark), the English High Sheriff of Lanark, in May 1297. He then joined with [the Hardy, Lord of Douglas](William)(William the Hardy, Lord of Douglas), and they carried out the [of Scone](raid)(raid of Scone). This was one of several rebellions taking place across Scotland, including those of several Scottish nobles and [Moray](Andrew)(Andrew Moray) in the north.Traquair pp.63–67

The uprising suffered a blow when the nobles submitted to the English at [Irvine](Irvine, Scotland) in July. Wallace and Moray were not involved, and continued their rebellions. Wallace used the [Forest](Ettrick)(Selkirkshire) as a base for raiding, and attacked [Wishart](Robert Wishart)'s palace at [Ancrum](Ancrum). Wallace and Moray met and joined their forces, possibly at the siege of Dundee in early September.Traquair pp. 70–73

#### Battle of Stirling Bridge

[[Bridge.jpg|thumb|left|The later Stirling Bridge](File:Stirling)]

On 11 September 1297, an army jointly led by Wallace and [Moray](Andrew)(Andrew Moray) won the [of Stirling Bridge](Battle)(Battle of Stirling Bridge). Although vastly outnumbered, the Scottish army routed the English army. [de Warenne, 6th Earl of Surrey](John)(John de Warenne, 6th Earl of Surrey)'s feudal army of 3,000 cavalry and 8,000 to 10,000 infantry met disaster as they crossed over to the north side of the river. The narrowness of the bridge prevented many soldiers from crossing together (possibly as few as three men abreast), so, while the English soldiers crossed, the Scots held back until half of them had passed and then killed the English as quickly as they could cross. The infantry were sent on first, followed by heavy cavalry. The Scots' [schiltron](schiltron) formations forced the infantry back into the advancing cavalry. A pivotal charge, led by one of Wallace's captains, caused some of the English soldiers to retreat as others pushed forward, and under the overwhelming weight, the bridge collapsed and many English soldiers drowned. Thus, the Scots won a significant victory, boosting the confidence of their army. [de Cressingham](Hugh)(Hugh de Cressingham), Edward's treasurer in Scotland, died in the fighting and it is reputed that his body was subsequently flayed and the skin cut into small pieces as tokens of the victory. The Lanercost Chronicle records that Wallace had "a broad strip [Cressingham's skin](of) ... taken from the head to the heel, to make therewith a [baldric](baldric)k for his sword".*Chronicle of Lanercost*, ed. H. Maxwell, vol. 1, p. 164.Traquair, p. 76

After the battle, Moray and Wallace assumed the title of Guardians of the Kingdom of Scotland on behalf of King [Balliol](John)(John Balliol). Moray died of wounds suffered on the battlefield sometime in late 1297.

Around November 1297, Wallace led a large-scale raid into northern England, through Northumberland and Cumberland.Traquair pp. 77–79

In a ceremony, at the 'Kirk o' the Forest' ([Selkirk](Selkirk, Scottish Borders)), towards the end of the year, Wallace was [knight](knight)ed. This would have been carried out by one of three Scottish earls—[Carrick](Robert the Bruce), [Strathearn](Maol Íosa III, Earl of Strathearn) or [Lennox](Maol Choluim I, Earl of Lennox).Traquair p. 79[John](Prebble,)(John Prebble) *The Lion in the North*

From 1297 to 1298, William Wallace held the title of "Guardian of the Kingdom of Scotland" (or simply "Guardian of Scotland"), ruling on behalf of the deposed King John Balliol. After the Scottish victory at the Battle of Stirling Bridge in September 1297, Wallace and Andrew Moray assumed this role together, but after Moray's death, Wallace became the sole Guardian. Wallace was also knighted during this period.

## Television, film, and pop culture

Over the years, List and his crimes have furnished inspiration for documentaries, television dramas and feature films. Examples include "Savior," the season 6, episode 16 of the television series *[& Order](Law)(Law & Order)*; the 1987 film *[Stepfather](The)(The Stepfather (1987 film))* and its [remake](2009)(The Stepfather (2009 film)); the 1993 film *[Day: The John List Story](Judgment)(Judgment Day: The John List Story)*, in which List was portrayed by [Blake](Robert)(Robert Blake (actor)); and the character [Söze](Keyser)(Keyser Söze) in the 1995 film *[Usual Suspects](The)(The Usual Suspects)*.*The Usual Suspects* DVD commentary featuring [Singer](Bryan)(Bryan Singer) and [McQuarrie](Christopher)(Christopher McQuarrie), [2000]. Retrieved September 27, 2002.

In 2008, [Walsh](John)(John Walsh (television host)), the host of ''America's Most Wanted'', donated the age-progressed bust by Frank Bender that played a pivotal role in List's apprehension to a forensic science exhibit at the [Museum of Crime & Punishment](National)(National Museum of Crime & Punishment) in [D.C.](Washington,)(Washington, D.C.), whose collection was later moved to [East](Alcatraz)(Alcatraz East) Crime Museum in [Forge, Tennessee](Pigeon)(Pigeon Forge, Tennessee).

A 1996 episode of the series *[Files](Forensic)(Forensic Files)* discussed the List murders. A 2003 episode of the [A&E](A&E (TV channel)) series *[Justice](American)(American Justice)* also detailed the case and featured an interview with List. In 2015, the story was covered in the season 2, episode 2 of the [Discovery](Investigation)(Investigation Discovery) TV series *[Worst Nightmare](Your)(Your Worst Nightmare)*. The episode, "Murder House", premiered on November 18, 2015.

The movie *A Killer Next Door*, based on the events that led to the capture of John List, was released In July 2020.

In 2022, NJ Advance Media released "Father Wants Us Dead," a podcast serial on the events.

Also in 2022, [Netflix](Netflix) released a seven-part dramatic fictional miniseries called *[Watcher](The)(The Watcher (2022 TV series))*. Although it is a work of fiction, much of the character John Graff was borrowed from the story of the John List murders.Nolfi, Joey (2022-10-14). ["The Watcher's Grisly John Graff Murder Sequence Is Based on True Story of a Family Massacre."](https://ew.com/tv/the-watcher-john-graff-true-story-john-list-family-murders/) *[Weekly](Entertainment)(Entertainment Weekly)*. Retrieved 2022-10-20.  Played by [Mantello](Joe)(Joe Mantello), much of John Graff's story was identical such as his being an accountant, attending a Lutheran church, and murdering his family members and live-in mother, along with leaving music playing in the house and planning an alibi that would cause the bodies to remain undiscovered for several weeks.

John List Society are a band from Atlanta, GA who play "Punk / hardcore songs about serial killers" https://www.instagram.com/johnlistsociety/

## Relocation, arrest, and trial

In 1971, as the [FBI](Federal Bureau of Investigation) later discovered, List had traveled by train from New Jersey first to Michigan, then to [Colorado](Colorado). He settled in [Denver](Denver, Colorado) in early 1972 and took an accounting job under the name Robert Peter "Bob" Clark, one of his college classmates (although the real Bob Clark later asserted that he had never known List). From 1979 to 1986, he was the comptroller at a paper-box manufacturer outside Denver. He joined a Lutheran congregation and ran a [pool](car)(car pool) for shut-in church members. At one religious gathering, he met an Army [PX](Base Exchange) clerk named Delores Miller and they were married in 1985. In February 1988, the couple moved to a house in the Brandermill neighborhood of [Virginia](Midlothian,)(Midlothian, Virginia), where List, still using the name Bob Clark, resumed work as an accountant at a small accounting firm, Maddrea, Joyner, Kirkham & Woody.

In 1972, List was proposed as a suspect in the [B. Cooper](D.)(D. B. Cooper) [piracy](air)(air piracy) case because of the timing of his disappearance (two weeks prior to the [hijacking](airline)(Aircraft hijacking)), multiple matches to the hijacker's description, and the reasoning that "a fugitive accused of mass murder has nothing to lose." List was questioned by FBI investigators after his capture, but he denied any involvement in the Cooper case. While his name is still occasionally mentioned in Cooper articles and documentaries, no direct evidence implicates him, and the FBI no longer considers him a suspect.

In May 1989, the 18-year-old crime was recounted on the [Fox](Fox Broadcasting Company) television program ''[Most Wanted](America's)(America's Most Wanted)'' during its first year on the air. The segment featured an [age-progressed](Age progression) clay [bust](Bust (sculpture)), sculpted by [forensic](forensic) artist [Bender](Frank)(Frank Bender), which turned out to bear a close resemblance to List's actual appearance. On June 1, less than two weeks after the broadcast, List was arrested at a [Richmond](Richmond, Virginia) accounting firm after a Denver neighbor recognized the description and alerted authorities. List continued to stand by his alias for several months, even after his 1989 [extradition](extradition) to [County, New Jersey](Union)(Union County, New Jersey); finally, faced with irrefutable evidence – including a [fingerprint](fingerprint) match with List's military records, as well as evidence found at the crime scene – he confessed his true identity on February 16, 1990.

At trial, List testified that his financial difficulties reached crisis level in 1971 when he was [off](laid)(laid off) with the closure of the Jersey City bank. To avoid sharing this humiliating development with his family, List engaged in the same routine and dress as when employed, leaving home each morning on schedule and spending the day at job interviews or at the Westfield train station, reading newspapers until it was time to come home. List diverted money from his mother's bank accounts to avoid default on his [mortgage](mortgage). As the year progressed, the family's financial problems became more strained; List encouraged his children to seek part-time work, ostensibly to teach them maturity and responsibility, but in actuality to help keep the family financially solvent.

He was also dealing with his wife's [alcoholism](alcoholism) and her untreated [syphilis](tertiary)(syphilis#Tertiary), contracted from her first husband and concealed for 18 years. According to trial testimony, Helen had pressured List into marriage by falsely claiming that she was pregnant, then insisted that they marry in [Maryland](Maryland), which did not require the premarital syphilis test mandated in most other states at the time. Though her health progressively deteriorated, she said nothing to List or her physicians until 1969, when a thorough workup revealed the condition. By then, progression of the disease combined with her excessive alcohol consumption had, according to testimony, "transformed her from an attractive young woman to an unkempt and paranoid [recluse](recluse)" who frequently – and often publicly – humiliated List, comparing his sexual prowess unfavorably with that of her first husband.

A court-appointed [psychiatrist](psychiatrist) testified that List suffered from [personality disorder](obsessive-compulsive)(obsessive-compulsive personality disorder), and that he saw only two solutions to his situation: accept [welfare](Social programs in the United States#Welfare), or kill his family and send their souls to [heaven](heaven). Welfare was an unacceptable option, he reasoned, because it would expose him and his family to ridicule and violate his [authoritarian](Authoritarian personality) father's teachings regarding the care and protection of family members.

On April 12, 1990, List was convicted of five counts of [degree murder](first)(first degree murder). At his sentencing hearing, he denied direct responsibility for his actions: "I feel that because of my mental state at the time, I was unaccountable for what happened. I ask all affected by this for their forgiveness, understanding and prayer." The judge was unpersuaded: "John Emil List is without remorse and without honor," he said. "After 18 years, five months and 22 days, it is now time for the voices of Helen, Alma, Patricia, Frederick and John F. List to rise from the grave." He imposed a sentence of five terms of [imprisonment](life)(life imprisonment), to be served consecutively, the maximum permissible penalty at the time.

List filed an [appeal](appeal) of his convictions on grounds that his judgment had been impaired by [stress disorder](post-traumatic)(post-traumatic stress disorder) due to his military service. He also argued that the letter he left behind at the crime scene, essentially his confession, was a confidential communication to his pastor and therefore inadmissible as evidence. A federal appeals court rejected both arguments.

List eventually expressed a degree of remorse for his crimes. "I wish I had never done what I did," he told [Chung](Connie)(Connie Chung) in 2002. "I've regretted my action and prayed for forgiveness ever since." When asked why he had not taken his own life, he said he believed that [suicide](suicide) would have [him from going to heaven](prevented)(Christian views on suicide), where he hoped to be reunited with his family.

The television program that featured an age-progressed bust of John List, which helped lead to his capture, was America's Most Wanted. The show aired a segment on List in May 1989, including the age-progressed clay bust created by forensic artist Frank Bender. Less than two weeks after the broadcast, John List was arrested after a tip from a viewer who recognized him.
